docs.lead_paragraph: As a single mother of three teenage boys, one of whom (now 16) is an addict, I would like to share a few additional perspectives. I am one of those parents who emptied my savings and went into debt to pay for my child's treatment. If my son had cancer or diabetes, the insurance company would have picked up the entire bill. I work for the New York State government and have full medical coverage for my children. My insurance company denied all medical claims for my son. Most adolescent addicts have a second diagnosis, such as depression, anxiety, A.D.H.D., cutting and eating disorders, and they may start self-medicating with drugs and alcohol at a young age. They should not be lost because the health-insurance industry has figured out ways to deny coverage for treatment of the disease of addiction. Marcia J. Sikowitz Brooklyn
docs.abstract: Marcia J Sikowitz letter scores health insurance industry for denying coverage for addiction treatment (Feb 6 David Sheff article)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR his winter vacation a year ago, Jude Fournier relaxed in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, and his biggest activity of the day was moving between his hotel room and the beach. Recently, Mr. Fournier was getting ready for another trip, but this time his biggest concern wasn't whether to bring an extra swimsuit. Malaria pills, a first-aid kit and nonperishable snacks were on his packing list as he prepared for a day-and-a-half journey to Colombo, Sri Lanka, to assist with the tsunami clean-up. ''I want to do more than write a check,'' said Mr. Fournier, a 47-year-old high school teacher in Santa Fe, N.M., who started looking for volunteer opportunities to Southeast Asia two days after the tsunami hit on Dec. 26. Mr. Fournier's two-week trip was organized through i-to-i, (800) 985-4864 and www.i-to-i.com, a profit-making British company, with an office in Denver, that sends travelers on volunteer excursions to 24 countries. In Sri Lanka, he joined other volunteers in putting up tents, passing out food and helping to rebuild a poor area in Moratuwa, a suburb of Colombo.

headline.main: More Vacationers Answer the Call to Help

docs.abstract: Amy Gunderson travel article on rise in number of vacationers, in wake of Asian tsunami, who are doing volunteer work at disaster sites around globe; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Volunteer vacations are not new, but the tsunami brought even more attention to this growing area of the travel industry.

docs.lead_paragraph: PAULINE PELLEGRINO was expecting a big baby. Ms. Pellegrino, a 37-year-old Leonia resident, said her doctor had estimated that her baby would weigh about 9 pounds. It was the day before Ms. Pellegrino's due date, and the baby showed no sign of being born soon. Big babies can often mean difficult deliveries and possible injury to both mother and child, so her doctor decided to try to induce labor with the drug Pitocin. It wasn't effective, so the dosage was increased, but then the baby's heartbeat became irregular; Ms. Pellegrino was then wheeled into the Englewood Hospital operating room for a swift Caesarean section. Her daughter weighed a normal 7 pounds 10 ounces.

headline.main: Not-So-Special Delivery: State Leads in C-Sections

docs.abstract: Article on high number of caesarean sections in New Jersey; preliminary data from National Center for Health Statistics show that New Jersey topped country in 2003 at 33.1 percent compared with 27.6 percent nationwide; reasons why C-sections are on rise in state include large population of older mothers who tend to have more risk factors during pregnancy, growing number of women who opt for C-sections for sake of convenience and skyrocketing cost of malpractice liability insurance for obstetricians; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Employees of the financially troubled Nassau Health Care Corporation overwhelmingly approved a new contract Feb. 10 that union leaders say virtually assures their members of their jobs through 2009. The corporation, which operates the Nassau University Medical Center in East Meadow, the A. Holly Patterson Extended Care Facility in Uniondale, and seven community health clinics, has laid off about 900 employees because of budget cuts since January 2002.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CONFESSIONS OF MAX TIVOLI, by Andrew Sean Greer. (Picador, $14.) Max Tivoli's misfortune in this novel is to be born in 1871, in San Francisco, with the appearance of a 70-year-old man, and regress through life to physiological infancy. This curse -- he is born an innocent child in an old man's body and dies a wise man in a child's body -- has one advantage: living in disguise, Max pursues his true love, Alice, three times over the course of his life. As Greer explores his hero's life, ''Max's sense of melancholy can be keenly affecting,'' Gary Krist wrote here. BLACK EARTH: A Journey Through Russia After the Fall, by Andrew Meier. (Norton, $15.95.) Meier, a Moscow correspondent for Time magazine from 1996 to 2001, recounts his travels across post-Soviet Russia. Visiting the ''distant corners of the old empire'' -- from the Chechnya war zone in the south to the polluted industrial city of Norilsk above the Arctic Circle -- Meier paints an unsettling picture of contemporary life in Russia.

docs.lead_paragraph: GOV. M. JODI RELL wants to cap jury awards in malpractice cases. While Gov. John G. Rowland proposed a cap of $250,000 on noneconomic financial verdicts, Mrs. Rell says $500,000 sounds like a better figure. So why did she just announce a series of proposals to reduce malpractice insurance premiums that did not include the Republican desire of imposing caps on jury awards? Political reality, she says.
docs.abstract: Maura Casey Political Memo column on Connecticut Gov M Jodi Rell's failure to include caps on jury awards in series of proposals to reduce malpractice insurance premiums (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Psychiatrists are among the few doctors who don't look at the organs they treat. Imagine an orthopedist setting a bone without taking an X-ray. It would be like an auto mechanic diagnosing a faulty radiator without popping the hood. You would think he was a crook. Yet that is just what psychiatrists typically do. Instead of looking at the brain, they rely on interviews, experience, hunches and trial and error. But that could soon change. Brain-scanning technology has already helped researchers identify abnormalities in the lobes of people with A.D.H.D., bipolar disorder, schizophrenia and other psychiatric ailments. Studies also suggest that it's possible to track physical changes resulting from the use of psychotherapy or medication. If scanners could uncover the signs of distinct mental illnesses in the soft folds of the brain, the way X-rays can reveal a tumor, and monitor treatment effectiveness, they would revolutionize psychiatry.

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 2-20-05: IDEA LAB

docs.abstract: Paul Raeburn article on how brain-scanning technology could help psychiatrists and psychotherapists diagnose and treat mental disorders; researchers are already identifying some abnormalities on scans, and studies suggest that that it may be possible to track physical changes resulting from use of psychotherapy or medication; Dr Daniel G Amen, controversial child and adult psychiatrist, says scans should be used now and holds that doctors who do not use them are ill-serving their patients; many researchers are scornful of his methods, but most agree that brain scans will soon be refined enough to be useful; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: How looking at a patient's brain might improve the diagnosis of psychiatric ailments.

docs.lead_paragraph: There's going to be another Ross Perot, and this time he's going to be younger. There's going to be a millionaire rising out of the country somewhere and he (or she) is going to lead a movement of people who are worried about federal deficits, who are offended by the horrendous burden seniors are placing on the young and who are disgusted by a legislative process that sometimes suggests that the government has lost all capacity for self-control. He's going to be set off by some event like what is happening right now with the Medicare prescription drug benefit. He's going to look at an event like that one, and he's not only going to be worried about the country's economic future -- he's also going to be morally offended. He's going to sense that something fundamentally decadent is going on.

headline.main: In the Midst of Budget Decadence, a Leader Will Arise

docs.abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column predicts that there is going to be millionaire rising out of country and he (or she) is going to lead movement of people who are worried about federal deficits and legislative process that suggests that government has lost its capacity for self-control; says he is going to be set off by some event like what is happening with Medicare prescription drug benefit; holds that he is going to sense that something fundamentally decadent is going on, and he is going to be right (M)
docs.snippet: The stage is set for the emergence of a leader who will launch not a green-eyeshade economic crusade, but a moral crusade.

docs.lead_paragraph: A flutter of hope that the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra would resume its season was silenced yesterday when the musicians rejected a contract offer after a negotiating session marked by confusion. They voted overwhelmingly in support of their negotiating committee, which had recommended rejecting the offer, said Len Leibowitz, the musicians' lawyer.

headline.main: St. Louis Orchestra Players Reject Offer

docs.abstract: Musicians of St Louis Symphony Orchestra vote overwhelmingly in support of their negotiating committee, which has recommended rejecting orchestra's contract offer; dispute is shaping up as one of bitterest at American orchestra in recent years; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The musicians voted overwhelmingly in support of their negotiating committee, which recommended rejecting the orchestra's latest offer.
